citeinfo.title: Shark River Site 3 Vertical Accretion Data (ver 2.0, July 2019)

descript.abstract: This data set represents vertical accretion data from Shark River site 3 in Everglades National Park.
descript.purpose: Marker horizons are used to measure vertical accretion due to sediment deposition or erosion. Marker horizons are often used in conjunction with sediment elevation tables to measure both surface and below-ground processes that influence elevation change.

cntperp.cntorg: Wetland and Aquatic Research Center, Wetland and Forested Ecosystems Branch

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

procstep.procdesc: Powdered white feldspar clay (or other inert materials such as sand, brick dusk, or glitter) is placed on the surface of the sediment in a designated plot. Cores are taken within this plot upon return visits to the site, and the thickness of the sediment accumulated above the marker layer is measured as vertical accretion.

Version History for Everglades National Park sediment elevation and marker horizon data release
Feher, L.C., Osland, M.J., and Anderson, G.H., 2019, Everglades National Park sediment elevation and marker horizon data release (ver 2.0, July 2019): U.S. Geological Survey data release, https://doi.org/10.5066/F7348HNP.
________________________________________________________
Original posted online August 10, 2017 ________________________________________________________
Version 2.0 revised and reposted online July 2019
Changes in version 2.0
1. Added several additional columns of sediment elevation and marker horizon data from sampling events from the period between September 2014 and April 2019. 2. Revised the SET pin height values collected prior to April 2019 to reflect the length of new fiberglass pins. Note that in some instances this conversion resulted in negative pin height values. 3. Added data from new marker horizon plots that were installed during the May 2017 or December 2018 sampling events. ________________________________________________________

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
